Package com.github.kbnt.java14.tb

Class TextBlocks

java.lang.Object
com.github.kbnt.java14.tb.TextBlocks
public class TextBlocks
extends java.lang.Object
This class dives into the JEP 368 (Text Blocks) enhancement proposal.

Note that Java 14 sees this JEP as a second preview, so this is not entirely new to Java 14.
Author:
Chris T

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    void example00OldWayVersusNewWay()
    A basic comparison between the old way of declaring long text fields and the way they can be.
    void example01Description()
    This method follows the most important aspects in the "Description" paragraph from the JEP documentation.

    Note that the trailing line policy requires a longer conversation and it is a little bit harder to document without proper visual support.
    void example03StringStripIndent()
    The text blocks feature is processed by the compiler in a particular way (full description in the mentioned JEP document section called Compile-time processing).
    Several APIs have been added that mimic this behavior and one of them is called stripIndent().
    void example04Inception()
    This is an ironical example making a reference to the Inception movie and the idea of a "dream in a dream".

    The example builds a SQL statement using the JS build in engine leveraging JavaScript's ES6 template literals all defined as text blocks in Java.

    The irony and analogy to the mentioned movie comes from the fact that: First, we demo the text blocks as a Java feature.
    void example05Java14NewEscapeSequences()
    The text blocks feature was in the preview mode since Java 13.

    Given the fact that the feature eliminates incidental white space and leverages multilines, two concerns occurred: What happens if a developer intentionally wants spaces at the beginning and at the end of the line? For this \s was introduced as an escape sequence to act "as a fence".

    • example01Description

      public void example01Description()
      This method follows the most important aspects in the "Description" paragraph from the JEP documentation.

      Note that the trailing line policy requires a longer conversation and it is a little bit harder to document without proper visual support. Therefore I recommend watching the video that actually shows how it works: TODO insert the video link here...

    • example03StringStripIndent

      public void example03StringStripIndent()
      The text blocks feature is processed by the compiler in a particular way (full description in the mentioned JEP document section called Compile-time processing).
      Several APIs have been added that mimic this behavior and one of them is called stripIndent(). This examples tries to show how the compiler processes the string.
      See Also:
      String.stripIndent()

    • example04Inception

      public void example04Inception() throws javax.script.ScriptException, java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
      This is an ironical example making a reference to the Inception movie and the idea of a "dream in a dream".

      The example builds a SQL statement using the JS build in engine leveraging JavaScript's ES6 template literals all defined as text blocks in Java.

      The irony and analogy to the mentioned movie comes from the fact that:
      • First, we demo the text blocks as a Java feature.
      • Secondly, we use text blocks from Java to define JavaScript (ES6) that leverages Template literals.
      • Thirdly, we use the template literals to produce a SQL statement.
      Notes:
      • it is uncertain what will happen with JS support in the future Java versions (JEP 335: Deprecate the Nashorn JavaScript Engine). Still, this is - at least for Java 14 - a good example for text blocks.
      • in order to enable the ES6 support in Nashorn, use the -Dnashorn.args=--language=es6.
      Throws:
      javax.script.ScriptException - when there was a problem running the script.
      java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - when performing dynamic invocation

    • example05Java14NewEscapeSequences

      public void example05Java14NewEscapeSequences()
      The text blocks feature was in the preview mode since Java 13.

      Given the fact that the feature eliminates incidental white space and leverages multilines, two concerns occurred:
      1. What happens if a developer intentionally wants spaces at the beginning and at the end of the line? For this \s was introduced as an escape sequence to act "as a fence".
      2. It is a common practice to split long lines using the "\" character if you use a linux shell. Probably inspired by this capability, a similar functionality has been introduced for text blocks.
      Attribution:
      • artwork by Joan Stark and published at https://www.asciiart.eu/computers/smileys.
      • oneliner joke from unknown author published at https://short-funny.com/one-liners.php
